The way I see this change is that, it's less about counter banning and more about banning what YOU don't want them to have. And sometimes it can result in them also feeling the same about a certain Champ. But that's just me :D

To me it seemed odd and kinda stupid at first that your ban might be overlapped, but I actually kind of like the idea.

I think knowing that your ban might be already banned creates a mindgame, so players have to weigh "is this ban likely to be overlapped" versus "is this ban really important to me"
In other words, you'll have to think harder about how much the ban is necessary, rather than checking your list of "permaban champions" to see which meta champion isn't banned yet.
Riot apparently thought this way too: "This also reduces the chance of certain meta champions being banned across every game."

Was it wasted though?  You chose to ban, let's say champion A, because you didn't want it in the game and after banning phase it won't be.  Yes I suppose if you knew that the other person was also going to be banning champion A you could've chosen another champion (let's say champion B) to ban but in the end you chose to ban champion A and not champion B for your own reasons.  Overall champion A, the champion you most wanted to ban won't be in game and to me that makes me feel like my ban did something.
Maybe you should think that it was the other team that wasted a ban? Also I am still confused how you think it is a waste ban. The champ isn't in the game...
If you ban yasuo and so does the enemy, you could have banned someone else instead and have 2 champs banned rather than 1.

Sure but you decided that the most important thing during ban phase was to keep Yasuo out of the game - AND YOU GOT IT.  The fact that someone else is happy that Yasuo isn't in the game is just gravy.  Even better is that you 'made them' waste a ban on Yas rather than someone you wanted to play.
Its a calculated risk. Ban what you find cancerous and risk a duplicate, or gamble the enemy will ban it for you.

No, you got exactly the ban you want AND managed to get the enemy team to waste a ban. 

Glass half full vs glass half empty.

Yeah I agree. The system should probably work with being able to see the enemy bans when they have locked in their ban pick. Once the champ is banned, no one else can ban it, just to secure 10 unique bans and not 9.

In that case, the optimal strategy would be to not lock in your ban.  If you want 2 champs banned, you would want to wait for the other team to lock in so that you can see which of the two you need to ban yourself.

**Tl;dr**

- The strategy of banning/building team comps should not be removed in favor of giving everyone a ban or reducing pick/ban phase time.
- Solo Queue banning should not be separated from competitive, it leads to confusion.
- This defeats the whole purpose of drafting if you can't plan around what the enemy team wants to do vs what you want to do.
- This will lead to an overall lesser amount of strategic growth where the only "new" professional players are the ones that get to high MMR based on mechanics/game knowledge rather than how to build a teamcomp and then having to relearn pick/banning.
   - This creates a delay in average skill growth rate that hampers the ability of the game to improve. 


So. Let me understand this. You (Riot) are introducing 5 bans for everyone. But giving no ban strategy because it doesn't matter? 

This defeats the whole purpose of drafting. Just let it be teambuilder ranked now. You say solo queue vs competitive has different needs but ban strategy is a very real thing for having insight into what the enemy team wants to ban. If we go through this then let us have mirror matchs.


I feel like this is Riot wanting to push it because they said they would instead of pushing something that is balanced/strategic.

Sure at low ELO it doesn't matter, people will ban who they don't want to play against.
Once you start climbing strategy is obviously more important. Why would we agree to that? 

Say we go into a game:

- Everyone decides we want to play a protect the Kog'maw comp
- Team A (Protect) bans divers/assassin
- Team B on the other hand someone just dislikes Kog'Maw
- Team B bans whatever + Kog'maw
- Team A is now at a disadvantage because the comp they wanted to play is now absolutely worthless and their bans don't matter anymore.

This is a huge step backwards for the game in terms of strategy.

Also would like to point out that the difference in competitive vs regular could be confusing/throw people off from wanting to get into League.

Example:
League of Legends is presented that this is the way it is played/drafted. 
Hey cool I like the way they do it and play, maybe I will try it out.
Sign-up/Download League and the drafting is nothing like I saw.

A) Stick it out and make do until I finally realize I don't like the way I was misinformed/lead to believe the game was.
B) Immediately go back to what I was playing or find something else because it is not what I thought it would be.

Of course you could always have the casters preface every pick/ban phase for new players:
"This is a different ban phase than what you will normally have because competitive gameplay has different needs than you scrubs."
This is hardly a "tl;dr", but thank you.

Your statement is probably valid for very-high elo, or ranked 5s. But for the vast of majority and solo queue player, teams hardly coordinate a strategy before they are in game. It is even more unlikely that teams will target ban based on team strategies. So for 99% of people this is a good start. 

This also made sure that we don't spend 10 min just on p/b phase.

Don't get me wrong. In lower MMR (Read below plat) this won't have much of a bad effect in my opinion.

At higher levels of play (Read Diamond+) it's detrimental to drafting phase.

Think about esports: How many times do they mention "They just got out drafted" or in soloqueue realizing that the loss was probably during drafting phase.

It's because it's an important part of the game, strategically. Not being able to respond to the enemy drafting phase isn't good for the health of the game. Overall I just feel that it leads to "dumbing" the game down and like my last "tldr" pointed out that it will decrease the quality of players. 

You hear people mention that the professional players now are vastly superior to the old for the most part because over-all there is more game knowledge. It's also a fact that it's because other people are better so they can improve even more. 

If the quality of each phase is increased (IE pick/ban being important) then the over-all gameplay is improved and you get better players.

If you're implying that players in lower elo don't try to exercise any strategy in the alternating ban phase, that isn't true at all. Even in Bronze V people frequently adjust their bans based on the other team's bans.

I just ban my lane counter or whatever is OP, down here in Silver/Gold elo. Idk what things are like in super high elo or whatever, but that is a tiny minority of the player base. 

"Sign-up/Download League and the drafting is nothing like I saw."

Actually, your solution doesn't solve this issue, because blind pick is the only mode available before you own 20 champions. 

But give people some credit, they aren't stupid. They aren't going to be confused by the fact that champion select is a little different, just the same way they aren't confused that not every game is a Bo3, that Ryze is the worst solo queue champion in the game, that there isn't any cheering crowds when they play, that they don't have to shake hands with their opponents when they finish the game. Those differences aren't going to make them quit League. You're delusional if you think that champ select is the thing that catches the interest of casual viewers. Try convincing someone who doesn't play League to watch a pro game, and I guarantee they will tell you that champ select was the most boring part.
Ban can duplicated across teams? I don't know about that one. I'd rather prefer if they didn't.
This means that there is the possibility that all five bans for each team are exactly the same. Which gives us a total of five bans (less than what we have now).
I agree with you but what if you have multiple Champs you don't like laning against and you banned the one that the enemy team banned? that would be a big waste.

The chances of this happening are extremely low in my opinion. If both teams ban the same 5 champions, that means they're dominating the meta and there's something wrong with game balance.

While certain champion, namely Yasuo and Zed, are likely going to see quite a few double bans, I think it will be very rare to only have 5 bans. So, even if 4 bans are duplicates, we're still at the same old 6 bans and everyone will be happy because they got to ban what they wanted. Either way, the same 6 champs would have been banned.

I think that once you lock in a ban, it could show up for both teams, but this would just cause people to wait until the last second before banning in hopes that someone else on the other team would ban the champion they plan on banning. Overall, it would just make the system a giant game of chicken. Besides, Riot is  encouraging players to target champs that counter their own picks, so seeing what other players target in this style will also change the way people are going to pick and counter pick and even counter ban.

At least in this select every person on the team will be able to choose 1 champion that they don't want to see in the game.  Rather than 3 people having that decision on each team.  In this draft people can ban out their worst laning opponent or in the case that they're confident with any match up use their ban to help out a teammate.  If you stop looking at the numbers (6 bans to 5 bans [again this is worst case scenario]) and strictly look at the reliability of bans and the strength of your bans you'll see that this way of banning is a lot more beneficial.
Yeah, not liking the idea that we could be going from 6 bans to 5 bans depending on who's banning.
